verses.text: Now Naomi had a relative on her husband’s side, a man of standing from the clan of Elimelech. His name was Boaz.
verses.comment: The phrase 'a man of wealth' can also mean 'mighty man of valor.'

verses.text: Ruth the Moabite said to Naomi, 'Let me go to the fields and pick up leftover grain behind anyone in whose eyes I find favor.' Naomi said to her, 'Go, my daughter.'
verses.comment: Gleaning was part of Israelite law for providing for the poor (see Lev. 19:9-10).

verses.text: So she went out and entered a field to glean behind the reapers. By chance, she came to a part of the field belonging to Boaz, who was from the clan of Elimelech.
verses.comment: The phrase 'by chance' highlights God’s providence.

verses.text: Just then Boaz came from Bethlehem and said to the reapers, ‘The LORD be with you.’ And they answered him, ‘The LORD bless you.’
verses.comment: Boaz’s greeting shows common Israelite blessings.

verses.text: Then Boaz said to his servant who was in charge of the reapers, 'Whose young woman is this?'
verses.comment: ‘Young woman’ denotes Ruth’s status as unmarried or widowed.

verses.text: The servant in charge of the reapers answered, 'She is the young Moabite woman who came back with Naomi from the land of Moab.'
verses.comment: Emphasizes Ruth’s Moabite origin for context.

verses.text: She said, ‘Please let me glean and gather among the sheaves after the reapers.’ So she came and has continued from early morning until now except for a short rest.
verses.comment: Focus on Ruth’s diligence and humility.

verses.text: Then Boaz said to Ruth, 'Listen to me, my daughter. Do not go to glean in another field or leave this one, but stay close to my servant girls.'
verses.comment: Boaz’s address as ‘my daughter’ shows respect and care.

verses.text: Keep your eyes on the field they are reaping, and follow after them. I have commanded the young men not to touch you. When you are thirsty, go to the jars and drink from what the young men have drawn.
verses.comment: Shows Boaz’s protection and inclusion for Ruth.

verses.text: Then she fell on her face, bowing to the ground, and said to him, 'Why have I found favor in your eyes, that you should take notice of me, since I am a foreigner?'
verses.comment: Ruth’s humility and gratitude highlighted.

verses.text: Boaz answered her, 'All that you have done for your mother-in-law since the death of your husband has been fully reported to me. How you left your father and mother and your homeland and came to a people you did not know before.'
verses.comment: Echoes Abraham’s call in Genesis 12:1.

verses.text: May the LORD repay you for your work, and a full reward be given to you from the LORD, the God of Israel, under whose wings you have come to seek refuge.'
verses.comment: ‘Under whose wings’ is an image of God’s care.

verses.text: Then she said, 'Let me find favor in your eyes, my lord, for you have comforted me and spoken kindly to your servant, though I am not even like one of your servant girls.'
verses.comment: ‘Spoken to the heart’—expression means kindly or encouragingly.

verses.text: At mealtime Boaz said to her, ‘Come here and eat some bread and dip your piece in the vinegar wine.’ So she sat beside the reapers, and he offered her roasted grain, and she ate until she was satisfied and had some left over.
verses.comment: ‘Vinegar wine’ is a sour drink made from wine or diluted vinegar.

verses.text: When she rose to glean, Boaz ordered his young men, ‘Let her glean even among the sheaves and do not shame her.’
verses.comment: Boaz’s generosity and protection go beyond custom.

verses.text: Also, pull out some stalks from the bundles for her and leave them for her to glean, and do not rebuke her.
verses.comment: Explicit instructions to deliberately provide extra for Ruth.

verses.text: So Ruth gleaned in the field until evening. Then she beat out what she had gleaned, and it was about an ephah of barley.
verses.comment: An ephah is about 22 liters or 5.8 gallons.

verses.text: She carried it back to the city, and her mother-in-law saw what she had collected. Ruth also brought out what she had left over after she had eaten and gave it to her.
verses.comment: Shows Ruth’s generosity toward Naomi.

verses.text: Her mother-in-law asked her, 'Where did you glean today? Where did you work? Blessed be the man who took notice of you.' So she told her mother-in-law with whom she had worked and said, 'The man’s name with whom I worked today is Boaz.'
verses.comment: Naomi’s blessing anticipates Boaz's kindness.

verses.text: Naomi said to her daughter-in-law, 'May he be blessed by the LORD, whose kindness has not forsaken the living or the dead.' And Naomi added, 'That man is a close relative of ours, one of our redeemers.'
verses.comment: ‘Redeemer’ refers to a kinsman who can redeem family property or persons.

verses.text: Then Ruth the Moabite said, 'He also told me, “Stay close to my servants until they have finished all my harvest.”'
verses.comment: Confirms Boaz’s ongoing protection.

verses.text: Naomi said to Ruth her daughter-in-law, 'It is good, my daughter, that you go out with his servant girls, so that you may not be harmed in another field.'
verses.comment: Naomi acknowledges Ruth’s safety among Boaz’s people.

verses.text: So she stayed close to the servant girls of Boaz, gleaning until the end of the barley and wheat harvests. And she lived with her mother-in-law.
verses.comment: Summarizes Ruth’s faithfulness through the harvest season.
